item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: How to Avert a Nuclear War
item.description: The greatest risk of error lies in early warning systems. Russia and America could eliminate this threat.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: JAMES E. CARTWRIGHT and VLADIMIR DVORKIN

item.title: ISIS Video Purports to Show Killing of Ethiopian Christians
item.description: The footage, if confirmed, would be the first evidence that the Islamic State’s leaders in Syria and Iraq are coordinating with fighters who have taken up the group’s banner in southern and eastern Libya.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: A video released on Sunday by the Islamic State appears to show fighters from affiliates in southern and eastern Libya executing dozens of Ethiopian Christians.

item.title: Hundreds Feared Dead After Boat Filled With Migrants Capsizes in Mediterranean
item.description: The boat overturned 70 miles north of Libya as a Portuguese vessel that the Italian authorities had diverted was approaching it early Sunday, the Italian Coast Guard said.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Sale of U.S. Arms Fuels the Wars of Arab States
item.description: A de facto alliance in the region against Iran has opened the way to more sales to Arab states, and raised fears of an arms race.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Qatar is seeking to purchase Boeing F-15 fighters to replace its aging French Mirage jets, above.

item.title: World Briefing: Spain: Couple Accused of Links to ISIS
item.description: Two residents of Spain’s North African enclave of Melilla are accused of having links to terrorists and membership in the Islamic State group.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Somalia: Regional Lawmaker Killed
item.description: Gunmen from the Shabab killed Aden Haji Hussein, a regional lawmaker, on Saturday in the capital, Mogadishu, officials said.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Mali: 2 Dead in Attack on U.N. Convoy
item.description: The attack killed two civilian workers, the United Nations peacekeeping mission said Saturday. Another member of the team was wounded but escaped with others in the convoy.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: 47 Indian Fishermen Arrested
item.description: The fishermen were accused of violating Pakistan’s territorial waters in the Arabian Sea, the police said. Pakistan’s Maritime Security Agency also seized eight boats, which it said had strayed into Pakistani waters.
item.dc:creator: AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: Brazil Aiming to Win When It Hosts Games
item.description: With Brazil set to host the 2016 Olympics, the nation’s focus turned to improving its medal count.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:credit: Dean Alberga/World Archery Federation, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The archer Marcus Vinicius D’Almeida is one of Brazil’s Olympic hopefuls for 2016.

item.title: China Cracks Down on the ‘Sport for Millionaires’
item.description: President Xi Jinping’s crackdown on corruption has a new target: the popular capitalist pastime of golf, derided by Mao as a rich man’s game.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A golf course in Shenyang, China. Party leaders in some provinces are discouraged from playing the sport during working hours.

item.title: Lawsuit in Spain Seeks Recognition of Another Dalí Creation: A Daughter
item.description: A lawsuit filed in March by Pilar Abel, a tarot card reader, claims that her mother had a “clandestine love affair” with the painter in the 1950s.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Myriam Meloni for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pilar Abel, 59, left, filed a lawsuit claiming that her mother, Antonia Martínez de Haro, 86, had an affair with Salvador Dalí.

item.title: Google’s Steely Foe in Europe
item.description: Margrethe Vestager, the European Union’s commissioner for competition, has a reputation for being tough, but she says it’s her responsibility to make sure that competition is fair and open.
item.dc:creator: NATASHA SINGER and JAMES KANTER
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: In certain circles, Margrethe Vestager is known as the “Iron Lady of Denmark.”

item.title: Israel and Palestinians Reach Tax Deal
item.description: Resolving a monthslong dispute, Israel will release $470 million in taxes collected on behalf of the Palestinians, after deductions for Palestinian debts.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: One Killed in Kashmir Valley Protest
item.description: The young man was killed on Saturday when police and security forces fired on stone-throwing protesters in the western part of the Kashmir Valley, the police said.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Protesters threw stones at police and security forces on Saturday on the outskirts of Srinagar in the Kashmir Valley.

item.title: Afghan President Blames ISIS for a Bombing
item.description: If the Islamic State’s role in a suicide bombing that killed 35 civilians on Saturday is confirmed, the attack would be a major escalation of the group’s activities in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: KHALID ALOKOZAY and ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: People ran for cover after an attack at a bank in Jalalabad, Afghanistan. It was one of three explosions in the city on Saturday. In addition to the deaths, 125 people were reported to be wounded.

item.title: Germanwings Crash Exposes History of Denial on Risk of Pilot Suicide
item.description: Investigations have exposed a series of failures and weaknesses throughout the airline industry in dealing with mental illness among pilots.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS KULISH and NICOLA CLARK
item.media:description: Rescuers at the site of the Germanwings crash near Seyne-les-Alpes, France, on March 30, six days after the plane smashed into the ground.

item.title: Kabul Journal: At Afghan Weddings, His Side, Her Side and 600 Strangers
item.description: Strangers seeking banquet fare arrive in droves as many seem to know this saying: “With a wedding every night, there is no need to go hungry.”
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Boys in dinner suits played one Friday this month in a parking lot outside Mumtaz Mahal, a wedding hall in Kabul, Afghanistan.

item.title: Australian Police Arrest 5 Men They Say Were Planning Terror Attacks
item.description: Two of the men, both 18, had been preparing to attack police officers in Melbourne during a national holiday, the authorities said Saturday.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Replica of Lafayette’s Frigate to Set Sail From France for a U.S. Visit
item.description: The full-size replica of the Hermione, which carried the Marquis de Lafayette to America in 1780, will visit several East Coast ports this summer.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Vivian Nicholson, Rags-to-Riches-to-Rags Icon, Dies at 79
item.description: Mrs. Nicholson was just 25 when she won a sports bet that paid more than £150,000, the equivalent today of about $4.5 million, and her life inspired a musical and a BBC television film.
item.dc:creator: MARGALIT FOX
item.media:description: Vivian Nicholson in 1961, after she and her husband won £152,300 predicting the outcomes of eight football matches.
